climbs.name: Chewbacca
climbs.fa: Sean Pickersgill, Bryan Kent, Joel Beckmann, Taran Ortlieb

content.description:
Fantastic new addition. Steep, varied climbing and a nice departure from the usual Squamish corner. All bolted anchors.

P1 - Easy face climbing leads to a short, steep tight hands/finger crack. 5.10-. Small ledge for the belay.

P2 - Fun chimney/slot with good gear. Felt about 5.9 tops to me. Huge belay ledge.

P3 - The money pitch. Climb the steep finger/hand crack until the little roof. While it looks like it should go up the corner, the climb tackles the short tight hand crack that angles right up the headwall. As that crack ends, step left onto a small ledge. Continue stepping left into the corner. The move stepping into the corner is a bit committing with your gear down and right of you (be sure to use slings). Find gear near the rock scar and make a face move out of the corner and slab up past a bolt to the top. The topo shows the crux as the face move exiting the corner, but I thought the crux was the angling hand crack. A long pitch, though the final 50' is easy.

More details available at Squamish Climbing Forum

Continue right past Skywalker for about 10 minutes until you come to a nicely made belay platform just left of the trail.
Standard rack to #3

This route is really good. Its getting dirty and needs more traffic so go and do it. Theres a chimney, good jamming, and even some jugs!! Starts in the big obvious chimney to the left of Chewbacca.
pull on the fixed line to get to an anchor and a belay seat(stump).
start from there. Good pro all the way, double rack is more than enough.

A spectacular and very sustained climb with great movement on face and crack. Can be done in one long pitch with good rope management. P1. 5.10b Climb the initial crack onto a platform. Make slabby moves left to the base of a steep dihedral. P2. 5.11b Climb the technical dihedral to the roof, traverse right towards a block making sure that your pro has long enough slings to avoid rope-drag. Layback up the very strenuous right-facing dihedral clipping three bolts along the way. Finally, power up the relentless corner crack. Note that McLane's 2005 book has the route numbering mixed up with Hunter's Moon. Hungry wolf is number 332 on the topo and Hunter's Moon is 231. This is near the south end of the wall, before it curves to face south. As you are scrambling uphill towards the base of Man of Leisure, a side trail breaks up and left to head back north. A quick scramble takes you to a little platform below a wide crack. Many small to medium nuts and finger to tight hand cams. A double set to hand size is advisable.

To descend, with double ropes you can rap the route or Man of Leisure, otherwise walk down east and then south.

To the left of Hungry Wolf is the somewhat improbable line of Hunters Moon. Same start as Hungry wolf, but continue out left past the big ledge below Hungry Wolf p2 to the arete. A hidden dike will appear on the arete just after the tricky slab move and offer temporary sanctuary. Clip the single bolt in the dike. From the awkward dike continue out right and up the thin crack that becomes a seemingly impossible flare. Some creative thinking sees you through this short but interesting section. Continue on up a slab to a treed ledge below a 5.10 face crack(p2-often dirty), ascend this to the shared anchors of Hungry Wolf.

Gobsmacking Wall. See Hungry Wolf description. 
Doubles to #1 Camalot, one #2. Much thin.

share the start with Hungry Wolf to the first belay stance located in the dihedral below the staircase of awesome roofs! Lycanthropy starts by stemming up the beautiful dihedral until met with the first roof, lean out and clip a shiny bolt and get ready to become a WOLF MAN! Smear, layback, hand jam, knee bar and pinch your way up the roofs past another couple bolts which reward you with a final section of stellar crack climbing on deep secure locks with a great position as you crest the wall. From the fixed station either rappel back down to the ground in two rappels ( 60 meter rope works fine) or scramble to the top of the wall and walk south back to your gear.

starts from the same ledge as the rest of the classics. Never Say Never, Hungry wolf, Flying squirrel to name a few. a fixed line or short easy scramble helps you gain the initial belay ledge.
3 bolts and a single rack from .4 - 2 will be more than enough, an extra .75 could be useful.

climbs.name: Man of Leisure
climbs.fa: Glen Payan, John Thompson, Jeff Thompson

content.description:
A long, high-quality route on beautiful stone.  It has some friction moves, some crack, some traversing on an intrusion/dyke, just about everything except an overhang.

The far south end of the wall at Shannon Falls curves around to face more towards the south.  Walk along the base of the cliff from the falls area until it curves up and around to a very nice clearing below a smooth face.  The route up the cracks in the face is Poultry in Motion, the more rounded buttress on the left is Man of Leisure.  The trail isn't heavily used, so it may take some false starts to get there.
Mostly bolts but a small selection of finger and hand sized nuts and cams is necessary.  Descent by rappel (but note that the route is longer than 100 feet) or by walking around to the east then south.

A sublime route. 
  
 A bit more technically difficult and heady than its bolted neighbor Hungry Wolf  (even though they share a similar grade in the guidebook),  Never Say Never may be one of the finest routes at the grade in Squamish IMHO. Start on a slab and into a corner that quickly steepens to overhanging. The crack begins as hands/fists and  narrows to fingers. The crux comes near the top of the corner as the locks become flaring, spaced out and insecure. Above the crack the difficulties continue...angle up and to the right on face features with finicky protection. Bolted Belay. 
  
 A thought provoking and demanding pitch. The gem of the crag.

Gobsmacking Wall. See Hungry Wolf description.
Doubles to #2 Camalot & one #3. Small to Medium Stoppers and small cams(small alien off-sets are very nice)...heavy on fingers and smaller.

From a belay bolt shared with Man of Leisure, move up and right into the finger crack. A long reach and delicate moves up and right bring you into another splitter hand and finger crack, which is followed to a slabby (bolted) topout.

The far south end of the wall at Shannon Falls curves around to face more towards the south. Walk along the base of the cliff from the falls area until it curves up and around to a very nice clearing below a smooth face. The route up the cracks in the face is Poultry in Motion, the more rounded buttress on the left is Man of Leisure.
One set of nuts and doubles in cams from fingers to 1"

Thin left facing corner with bolts and some small gear placements in the crack.  Some face climbing below then laybacking the thin crack and stemming the corner/some slab moves.  The crux is at the 3rd bolt.  Fun route that deserves more attention.  Longer than 35m so you won't be able to lower even with a 70m rope (not to mention it's just a tree with no tat at the top).

The route to the right of Poultry in Motion/Man of Leisure.  You should see numerous bolts from below but be sure to bring some gear too.
#2 if you want to protect before the first bolt & small cams for above (I used an x4 .2 & c4 .4) + 5 draws and something to wrap a tree up top.
This steep angled cliff lays to the right of Shannon Falls Wall.
